questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.
  • ➤ Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide:
  • • Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.
  • • Option C. Oligomycin:
  • • Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.
  • • Option D. Antimycin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Duodenum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.
  • • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview :
  • • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview
  • • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors. The main features of MEN 1 include: Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas. Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • • The main features of MEN 1 include: Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas. Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas. Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
  • • Parathyroid tumors
  • • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
  • • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs)
  • • Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • Pituitary tumors
  • • Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome :
  • • Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
  • • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.
  • • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.
  • • Option A. Jejunum:
  • • Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.
  • • Option B. Ileum:
  • • Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.
  • • Option D. Stomach:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023) Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive HBsAg: Positive Anti-HBs: Negative Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

Ans. B) Ligature strangulation

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the father’s death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their son’s, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

  • ➤ Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.

questions.text: Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022) Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg Baby on artificial feeds Baby of working mother/single parent Baby with weight <85% of expected weight Birth order of 3 or more

Ans. A) 2, 3

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation: Ans. A) Caspase – 1

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the least common opportunistic fungus known to cause pulmonary infections in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sporothrix is the least common opportunistic fungus among the given options to cause pulmonary infections in children. Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes sporotrichosis, which is typically a cutaneous infection that follows traumatic inoculation of the fungus into the skin, often through rose thorns or splinters (hence its nickname "rose gardener's disease"). Pulmonary sporotrichosis is extremely rare, especially in children, and is not typically considered among the common opportunistic pulmonary fungal infections.
  • • The other listed fungi are more commonly associated with pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect . Aspergillus is a common cause of opportunistic pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with prolonged neutropenia, chronic granulomatous disease, or those on long-term corticosteroid therapy. It can cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, and aspergilloma.
  • • Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect
  • • Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect . Cryptococcus (particularly C. neoformans) is a significant cause of pulmonary and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with HIV/AIDS or on immunosuppressive therapy. Pulmonary cryptococcosis is more common than pulmonary sporotrichosis.
  • • Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Mucor - Incorrect . Mucor species (causing mucormycosis) are increasingly recognized as important opportunistic fungi in immunocompromised children, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, prolonged neutropenia, or those receiving deferoxamine therapy. Rhinocerebral and pulmonary mucormycosis are the most common clinical presentations.
  • • Option D. Mucor - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes cutaneous sporotrichosis following traumatic inoculation and is rarely associated with pulmonary infections in children, unlike Aspergillus, Cryptococcus, and Mucor species, which are more common opportunistic pulmonary pathogens in immunocompromised pediatric patients.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy develops a dirty wound on his foot. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Debride and dressing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of a neuropathic or trophic ulcer in a leprosy patient, the first step should be debridement and dressing to clean the wound. This is followed by comprehensive foot care and rehabilitation to support healing and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy:
  • • Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.
  • • Option C. Wait and watch:
  • • Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.
  • • Option D. CT scan:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: True about acute tenosynovitis is:(NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A

Ans. D) Pain on passive extension of finger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons. It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus. Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.
  • • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Wernicke's area : Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.
  • • Option B. Wernicke's area
  • • Option C. Auditory area : Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.
  • • Option C. Auditory area
  • • Option D. Visual area : Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.
  • • Option D. Visual area

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice. This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.
  • ➤ In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transverse lie

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Transverse lie: Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.
  • • Transverse lie:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Abortion: Spontaneous abortion is a potential complication associated with uterus didelphys due to the structural anomaly affecting the uterine environment.
  • • Option A. Abortion:
  • • Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.
  • • Option B. Endometriosis:
  • • Option C. Preterm labor: Preterm labor is a recognized complication in patients with uterus didelphys. The abnormal structure of the uterus can lead to difficulties in carrying the pregnancy to full term.
  • • Option C. Preterm labor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterus didelphys is associated with complications such as spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and endometriosis, but it is less likely to cause a transverse lie, which is more common in arcuate or sub-septate uteri.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: A. Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 224
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.
